# Implementation Plan: InfoJira Dashboard

**Branch**: `001-infojira-dashboard` | **Date**: 2025-12-22 | **Spec**: [spec.md](spec.md)
**Input**: Feature specification from `specs/001-infojira-dashboard/spec.md`

**Note**: This plan is generated by the `/speckit.plan` command following the workflow in `.specify/templates/commands/plan.md`.

## Summary

InfoJira Dashboard is a modern, responsive web application that provides technical support teams with real-time visibility into JIRA project health through KPIs, charts, and detailed issue tables. The application enables users to filter by project (mandatory), issue type, and AP Area, displaying four key metrics (total open issues, critical issues, average resolution time, SLA violations), interactive charts (bar chart for issue status, pie chart for priority distribution), and a searchable, sortable issues table. Initially using mock JSON data, the system is architected for seamless future integration with the live JIRA REST API.

## Technical Context

**Language/Version**: Python 3.11+
**Primary Dependencies**: Flask 3.0+, Chart.js 4.4+, Tailwind CSS 3.4+
**Storage**: SQLite (development/test), PostgreSQL 15+ (production)
**Testing**: pytest 7.4+, pytest-flask, pytest-cov
**Target Platform**: Web browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge - latest 2 versions), deployed on Linux server
**Project Type**: Web application (Flask backend + HTML/CSS/JS frontend with Jinja2 templates)
**Performance Goals**: <2s dashboard load (p95), <500ms filter operations (p95), <200ms table sort (p95), <1s chart rendering for 500 issues
**Constraints**: <512MB backend memory footprint, <100ms database queries (p95), WCAG AA accessibility compliance
**Scale/Scope**: Support 3-10 JIRA projects initially, 10-1000 issues per project, 10-50 concurrent users

## Project Structure

### Documentation (this feature)

```text
specs/001-infojira-dashboard/
├── spec.md              # Feature specification (completed)
├── plan.md              # This file (/speckit.plan command output)
├── research.md          # Phase 0 output (technology decisions and patterns)
├── data-model.md        # Phase 1 output (entity schemas and relationships)
├── quickstart.md        # Phase 1 output (setup and run instructions)
├── contracts/           # Phase 1 output (API endpoint specifications)
│   ├── dashboard-api.yaml    # OpenAPI spec for dashboard endpoints
│   └── jira-mock-data.json   # Mock data structure matching JIRA API
├── checklists/          # Validation checklists
│   └── requirements.md  # Spec quality checklist (completed)
└── tasks.md             # Phase 2 output (/speckit.tasks command - NOT created by /speckit.plan)
```

### Source Code (repository root)

```text
backend/
├── src/
│   ├── __init__.py
│   ├── app.py                    # Flask application factory
│   ├── config.py                 # Configuration management (dev/test/prod)
│   ├── models/
│   │   ├── __init__.py
│   │   ├── project.py            # Project entity model
│   │   ├── issue.py              # Issue entity model
│   │   └── database.py           # SQLAlchemy setup and session management
│   ├── services/
│   │   ├── __init__.py
│   │   ├── data_provider.py     # Abstract data provider interface
│   │   ├── mock_data_service.py # Mock JSON data implementation
│   │   ├── jira_api_service.py  # Future JIRA API implementation (stub)
│   │   ├── kpi_calculator.py    # KPI calculation logic
│   │   └── filter_service.py    # Filter and search logic
│   ├── routes/
│   │   ├── __init__.py
│   │   ├── dashboard.py         # Dashboard view routes
│   │   └── api.py               # JSON API endpoints for AJAX
│   ├── templates/
│   │   ├── base.html            # Base template with Tailwind CSS
│   │   ├── dashboard.html       # Main dashboard view
│   │   └── components/          # Reusable template components
│   │       ├── kpi_card.html
│   │       ├── filters.html
│   │       ├── charts.html
│   │       └── issues_table.html
│   └── static/
│       ├── css/
│       │   └── custom.css       # Custom Tailwind extensions
│       ├── js/
│       │   ├── dashboard.js     # Dashboard interaction logic
│       │   ├── charts.js        # Chart.js configuration
│       │   ├── filters.js       # Filter handling
│       │   └── table.js         # Table sorting and pagination
│       └── data/
│           └── mock_jira.json   # Mock JIRA data
└── tests/
    ├── conftest.py              # pytest fixtures and configuration
    ├── unit/
    │   ├── test_kpi_calculator.py
    │   ├── test_filter_service.py
    │   ├── test_models.py
    │   └── test_data_provider.py
    ├── integration/
    │   ├── test_dashboard_routes.py
    │   ├── test_api_endpoints.py
    │   └── test_database.py
    └── contract/
        └── test_jira_api_contract.py

frontend/
├── package.json              # Node.js dependencies (Tailwind CSS tooling)
├── tailwind.config.js        # Tailwind CSS configuration
├── postcss.config.js         # PostCSS configuration
└── node_modules/             # (gitignored)

.
├── requirements.txt          # Python dependencies
├── requirements-dev.txt      # Development dependencies (pytest, black, etc.)
├── .env.example              # Environment variable template
├── .gitignore
├── README.md                 # Project overview and setup instructions
└── run.py                    # Application entry point
```

**Structure Decision**: Selected **Option 2: Web application** with separate backend and frontend directories. This structure is chosen because:

1. **Clear separation**: Backend (Flask/Python) and frontend (Tailwind/Chart.js) concerns are distinct
2. **Scalability**: Allows independent development and potential future API-only deployment
3. **Maintainability**: Developers can work on backend logic without touching frontend assets
4. **Build process**: Frontend requires Node.js tooling (Tailwind compilation), backend does not
5. **Testing isolation**: Backend and frontend tests are clearly separated

The frontend directory primarily contains build tooling (Tailwind CSS compilation). The actual rendered templates reside in `backend/src/templates/` and `backend/src/static/` following Flask conventions.
